text:
A Mobile App for Police to Track Car Status
Summary of Final Year Project

Bekkari Haithem
Drihem Abdelmoumen
Supervisor: Prof. Mohammed Amine Yagoub
Academic Year: 2024/2025
April 30, 2025
Abstract

The objective of our final year project is the design and development of a mobile applica-
tion, "PolicePlus," dedicated to police forces for tracking and managing the status of vehicles.
This project aims to address challenges such as rapid verification of vehicle information, real-
time detection of infractions (e.g., stolen status, expired documents), and optimization of law
enforcement interventions. The application enables officers to scan license plates or manually
query vehicle data, instantly accessing registered information, reporting anomalies, and facilitat-
ing administrative document verification via an intuitive interface. Key technologies employed
include Kotlin with Jetpack Compose for the Android application, Node.js with Express for the
backend API, MySQL for the database, and UML for system modeling. The system integrates
with external data sources like insurance databases and leverages tools like Retrofit, Dagger Hilt,
Figma, Git, and cloud deployment platforms (Render, Clever Cloud). This summary outlines
the projectâ€™s context, design methodology, implementation details, and key features.

Keywords: Mobile Application, Police, Vehicle Management, Car Status Tracker, License Plate
Recognition, UML, Kotlin, Jetpack Compose, Node.js, Express, MySQL, API, Android.

Chapter 1
Introduction

Today, the world is witnessing significant technological advancements in all sectors, particularly
in road safety and vehicle tracking. Modern technologies now enable law enforcement agencies to
use mobile applications to monitor and manage vehicle status in real time. Police officers often
face numerous challenges, such as quickly identifying vehicles, verifying documents, and detecting
infractions. Thanks to computing and web services, it is now possible to enhance the efficiency
of these operations by automating the process of vehicle control and tracking. In this context,
we have been led to design, develop, and implement a mobile application dedicated to vehicle
management by the police. This application aims to centralize information, provide instant access
to vehicle data, and facilitate officersâ€™ interventions in the field. Our application is designed to
improve vehicle management and optimize law enforcement operations to enhance the reliability
of inspections, reduce response times, and minimize human errors. This project consists of three
chapters presented as follows: Â·The first chapter is dedicated to the theoretical presentation and
functional requirements. Â·Chapter II provides several UML diagrams and specifications. Â·Chapter
III allows for the visualization and understanding of different system interfaces. Finally, we will
conclude this report with a summary of the work accomplished and an introduction to future
perspectives for this project.
Chapter 2
System Context

This chapter provides a general overview of the work context and the objectives of our final year
project. We will begin by outlining some of the challenges faced by law enforcement and the
importance of an information system for police operations.
Importance of Police Role and Security Measures

The police play a crucial role in ensuring road and vehicle safety by implementing security mea-
sures to reduce violations related to vehicle conditions. Ensuring that vehicles are roadworthy is
essential to prevent accidents caused by mechanical failures or the deterioration of critical com-
ponents. The police conduct regular inspection campaigns to detect vehicles that do not meet legal
standards, such as those with faulty brakes, lighting, or tires, which may pose risks to drivers and
pedestrians. They also impose fines and penalties on violators to ensure compliance with laws
designed to enhance road safety. In addition, the police contribute to raising awareness among
drivers about the importance of regular vehicle maintenance through educational and awareness
programs. They also utilize modern technologies, such as smart cameras and electronic inspec-
tion devices, to monitor vehicle conditions and effectively detect violations. Thus, the role of the
police in enforcing security measures is not limited to imposing laws but also includes promoting
a culture of road safety awareness, which helps reduce accident rates and ensures a safer traffic
environment for everyone.
2.2 Role of the PolicePlus System
digital system can significantly improve police operations by offering:
â€¢ Automatic license plate recognition and vehicle status tracking.
â€¢ Quick and efficient vehicle information retrieval.
â€¢ Secure storage and access to records.
â€¢ Integration with relevant external databases.
â€¢ Real-time data updates.
2.3 Current Vehicle Monitoring and Challenges

Ensuring road safety is a key responsibility of law enforcement. Police officers monitor vehicles
using five essential documents to verify compliance with legal and mechanical standards:
â€¢ Driverâ€™s License: Confirms the driver is authorized to operate a vehicle. Expired or invalid licenses are violations.
â€¢ Vehicle Registration Certificate: Verifies legal ownership and registration status, pre- venting fraud or use of stolen vehicles.
â€¢ Insurance Certificate: Ensures the vehicle has valid insurance coverage to protect road users.
â€¢ Technical Inspection Certificate: Confirms the vehicle has passed mechanical and safety inspections.
â€¢ Tax Receipt: Proves vehicle taxes are paid, required for legal operation.
Figure 2.1: Diagram of Key Documents and Possible Driver Violations
Operational Challenges
Despite their critical role, police operations face limitations:
â€¢ Manual document verification is slow and error-prone.
â€¢ Paper-based records risk loss, damage, and limited storage.
â€¢ Lack of real-time access hampers efficiency and decision-making.
â€¢ Difficulties in data analysis and reporting.
â€¢ No streamlined system for plate recognition or quick record retrieval.
Conclusion

While current procedures support enforcement, they suffer from inefficiencies. The next chapter
will outline a smart system designed to automate and enhance vehicle inspection and data access.
Chapter 3
System Design
3.1 Needs Analysis and UML Modeling
Introduction to UML

Unified Modeling Language (UML) is a standardized modeling language used to visualize the
design of a system. It provides a set of diagrams to represent the structure and behavior of a
system, making it easier to communicate ideas and designs among stakeholders. UML diagrams
are used in the object-oriented design process to outline the system architecture, interactions,
and flows.
Key UML diagrams include:
â€¢ Use Case Diagram: Shows the interactions between users (actors) and the system, highlighting system functionality.
â€¢ Class Diagram: Describes the structure of the system by showing the systemâ€™s classes, their attributes, and relationships.
â€¢ Sequence Diagram: Represents the interactions between objects in a sequential order.
â€¢ Activity Diagram: Depicts the flow of control or data through the system.
3.3 Main Actors in the System

In the context of the police officerâ€™s app for vehicle tracking and violations, the main actors are
as follows:

â€¢ Police Officer: The primary user of the system. Police officers can register or log in,
scan license plates to identify vehicles, view vehicle status (insurance, stolen status, etc.),
file tickets for violations, and report stolen cars.

â€¢ Traffic Management: Manages and populates the database with car, officer, and vio-
lation records. They ensure the system has up-to-date data for the police officers to use
during their interactions with the app.

â€¢ Car Owner (Implicit): While the car owner is not directly interacting with the system,
they are an essential data subject. The car owner can report a stolen car through a separate
interface or be impacted when a car is flagged as stolen by the police.
Actor
Police Officer
Table 3.1: Key System Actors and Roles
Role

Register/login, scan plates, view status, file tickets, report
stolen cars.
Traffic Management
Populate/manage database (cars, officers, violations).
Car Owner (Implicit)

Data subject, may interact via separate interface to report
stolen car.

Corresponding sequence and class diagrams are shown in Figures 3.5 and 3.6.

Use Case Diagrams

car reports and ticket submissions.
3.4.5 Database Relationships and Schema

The police system integrates data across multiple tables, such as users, officers, cars, tickets,
and insurance. Relationships include:
â€¢ One-to-one between cars and insurance using license_plate.
â€¢ One-to-many from officers to tickets.
â€¢ Many-to-one from tickets to normal users via driver_license.
â€¢ Cars linked to users through driver_license.
â€¢ Stolen car reports modify the stolen_car status in the cars table.
Figure 3.4: Use Case Diagram â€“ Car Status
Figure 3.5: Sequence Diagram â€“ Car Status
3.4.6 Unified Class Diagram and Schema Transition

Figure 3.15 shows the comprehensive class diagram, and the following schema was derived from
it to support database implementation.
Tables include:
â€¢ users, officers, normal_users, cars, tickets, insurance
Each table includes fields with appropriate types and constraints as outlined in the accom- panying data dictionary.
3.4.7 Conclusion

This section summarized the systemâ€™s high-level structure using UML diagrams and relational

the system.

Chapter 4
System Implementation

The system is designed to facilitate the tracking of vehicles by police officers, utilizing modern
mobile and backend technologies. The implementation focuses on providing a seamless user
experience with a well-structured backend to handle vehicle data, along with efficient tools for
managing and storing this information.
4.1 Development Tools and Technologies

The development of the application involved a combination of tools and technologies that ensured
efficient coding practices, scalability, and high performance.
Key technologies included:
â€¢ Mobile App: Kotlin, Jetpack Compose, Android Studio, Room (local DB), Dagger Hilt
(DI), Retrofit (API client).
â€¢ Backend API: Node.js, Express, MySQL (database).
â€¢ Deployment: Render (API), Clever Cloud (DB).
â€¢ Design & Collaboration: Figma, Git/GitHub, Postman.
4.2 Application Presentation

The application is designed to simplify the process of tracking vehicles for police officers, pro-
viding easy access to critical vehicle data such as insurance details, stolen status, and ticket
information. The following section summarizes the user flow and highlights the key interfaces
that make up the app.
4.2.1 Scenario Overview

The primary goal of the application is to allow a police officer to quickly search for vehicle
information using a license plate number. After logging into the app, the officer can initiate a
license plate scan or enter a plate number manually. The system fetches relevant data such as

ownership, insurance status, and any tickets associated with the vehicle. In addition to the scan
and search features, the officer can view their profile and access a history of scanned vehicles.
4.2.2 Key Application Interfaces

The application has been designed with a user-friendly interface, ensuring that police officers
can easily interact with it during their patrols. The following are some key screenshots of the
app:
Figure 4.1: Police Officer Login (Left) and License Plate Scan Interface (Right).
The login screen allows officers to securely log into their accounts, while the license plate scan interface enables them to capture license plate images for quick data retrieval.

After scanning a license plate, the officer is presented with relevant vehicle data, including
ownership and insurance details. The officerâ€™s profile screen offers a summary of their scanned
vehicle history and other personal information.
Figure 4.2: Vehicle Data Display (Left) and Officer Profile Screen (Right).
General Conclusion

This project focuses on tracking vehicle statuses and assisting police officers in verifying vehicle-
related information. We have developed an application that enables law enforcement to efficiently
access and manage vehicle data in real time. The application allows police officers to check essen-
tial vehicle documents, including the registration certificate, driverâ€™s license, insurance details,
technical inspection status, and tax receipts. It also facilitates quick identification of anomalies,
such as stolen vehicles or expired documents. Additionally, officers can receive alerts and take
immediate action when necessary. For the development of our application, we used Android Stu-
dio, Adobe Figma, and MySQL. We also plan to enhance the system with offline functionality
and more security measures to improve efficiency and reliability.
